docs.lead_paragraph: How should we set priorities in medical research? Officials at the National Institutes of Health will grapple with this question as they allocate billions of dollars from the agency's budget this year. Two geneticists, Dr. Kathleen Merikangas of the National Institute of Mental Health and Dr. Neil Risch of Stanford University, have taken on this challenge by introducing an intriguing framework for setting priorities for genetic research.

headline.main: Some Gene Research Just Isn't Worth the Money

docs.abstract: Each year National Institutes of Health determines allocation of billions of medical research dollars, some of which will go to fund genetic research; geneticists Dr Kathleen Merikangas of National Institute of Mental Health and Dr Neil Risch of Stanford University have developed proposal that ranks disorders they believe should receive priority status and bulk of genetic research dollars; report, which is published in journal Science, asserts that best candidates for genetic research are disorders whose onset and course cannot be impacted by environmental changes or personal habits; Type 2 diabetes, for example, can generally be avoided by eating right and getting proper exercise; addictions, such as smoking and alcohol, are therefore ranked as low priority disorders for genetic research; critics argue that other factors should be considered and note that health and social costs of addiction can exceed $500 billion a year; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: No one can dispute addiction's high cost. But is genetic research the best way to reduce it? Probably not.

byline.original: By KEITH HUMPHREYS and SALLY SATEL

docs.lead_paragraph: It looks like a set of above-ground swimming pools being used to pump up two giant, sky-blue water beds in a roadside meadow. And rain or shine, there is always a swarm of men tending to it. The equipment, brought here by the German Red Cross, is a mobile water purification plant, being used to provide clean drinking water for about 20,000 people in this region, some in refugee camps and some in homes with wells contaminated by the surge of salt water from the tsunami.
docs.abstract: Mobile water purification plant, provided by German Red Cross, is being used to furnish clean drinking water to about 20,000 refugees of December Tsunami living in Pottuvil, Sri Lanka; process of cleaning water described; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Providing safe drinking water is the single most important measure needed to prevent epidemics when water supplies are destroyed or polluted.
